plants.name: Rudbeckia hirta
plants.description: A North American native wildflower featuring bright yellow petals surrounding a dark brown central cone. Often found in meadows and prairies, it is hardy and attracts pollinators.
plants.funFact: Black-eyed Susans are the state flower of Maryland and coneflowers in the same genus are closely related.

plants.name: Dahlia pinnata
plants.description: A vibrant garden perennial with large, colorful, often pom-pom shaped flowers. Native to Mexico and Central America, dahlias bloom late summer through fall, making them popular in September gardens worldwide.
plants.location: Native to Mexico; widely cultivated worldwide
plants.funFact: Dahlias come in more flower forms than any other genus, including single, double, cactus, and pompon shapes.

plants.name: Hydrangea macrophylla
plants.description: A shrub known for large, globe-shaped flower clusters that can appear in pink, blue, or white depending on soil acidity. Blooms often last through September in mild climates.
plants.funFact: The flower color changes with the soil pH: acidic soils produce blue flowers, alkaline soils yield pink flowers.

plants.name: Echinacea purpurea
plants.description: A tall wildflower native to North America, recognized by its purple petals and prominent orange-brown central cone. Blooms late summer to early fall and attracts butterflies and bees.
plants.funFact: Echinacea is valued for its traditional medicinal uses to boost immune health.
